1120605802400636928.text: You could also flip it and have the employer send the offer to the candidate.  This way the candidate would walk away from the negotiation at least with a better understanding of their worth to that company, but without telling the company how much they demand.

1120605462028664833.text: Why? Like I said at the beginning, useless shower idea. It would allow the candidate to be confident that the employer had a number in mind _before_ they submitted their demand so it wasn't just a failure to negotiate, the company simply didn't believe the candidate was worth it.

1119572302532792322.text: Every other service I use makes it easy for me to give them money.  Why @Microsoft do you make it so amazingly hard for me to give you money to use your services!  Simple billing management is a well solved problem, _even for enterprise companies_.  Yet somehow you have failed.

1119572074358431744.text: All in all, I have spent dozens if not hundreds of hours over the years dealing with Microsoft account/billing problems.  This is just the latest, but likely the straw that breaks the camels back and causes me to drop my MSDN subscription and switch to AWS/GCE/Linux.

1119571824348516353.text: So just to be able to change my billing address, I need to migrate every Azure service I use to another subscription.  Many Azure services don't support migration, so for these I need to re-create everything I had previously setup just for me to migrate them.

1119571543732785152.text: Contacting support once again, they tell me that the only solution for me is to create a new account with my new billing country and then migrate all of my services to this new account!

1119571292015824896.text: Unfortunately, Azure wouldn't let me delete my card because it was still attached to a subscription.  However, the card I just added to my MS account wasn't listed.  When I tried to add the card via the Azure UI it only has an option for US billing address.

1119571121647472640.text: Once I was finally able to see my billing details, I updated them with my Microsoft account (the thing I sign-in with) and tried to delete my old card, but it said my old card was still used with some services (like Azure).

1119570923609153536.text: After working with support, it turns out that it was because I had an email address alias setup that I was logging in with instead of the primary account email address, so I updated my email address... in about a dozen different locations across the Microsoft offering...

1119570749579116545.text: Then I got to my MSDN subscription, which is paid annually and gets me some Azure credits as well as access to a number of other Microsoft products and services.  For starters, my account was in a state where I couldn't actually update my billing details at all without support.

1119570473304641542.text: My US credit card is expiring so I had to update my billing information for every online service I use.  For almost all of them, this was a 5 minute task that involved easily locating the billing section, putting in a new card with a new non-US billing address.

1119570213324775424.text: My frustration with @Microsoft and @Azure has finally boiled over. I like their products, I like their company, but their billing/account management system is an amazingly horrific and unusable mess that has provided me with the worst experience of any product I have ever managed

1119531966670360576.text: I thought the idea was that ENS was censorship resistant, not "just wrench attack 4/7 of these well known individuals"?

1073458718400864257.text: I would love to operate a business which simply delights its customers, but it is very hard to compete without engaging in any of the above.  You have to do an order of magnitude better than your competition to succeed against such tactics, no opportunity for iteratively better.

1073458391039729664.text: Sad Rant: I find it unfortunate that some of the most successful business models include aggressive sales, tricking customers, regulatory capture, and a bunch of other things other than "make customers happy".

1071279445355323392.text: On top of that, in what world is "how do I use (a customer) use this feature" a trade secret?

1071279142417494017.text: They tried to argue that I may be a competitor trying to get information about their product.  This is the most ridiculous thing I have heard.  If I was a competitor, I could just give theme the information they demanded and play along!

1071278427565486080.text: Pro Tip for losing customers fast: when they ask you a question about your product, demand sales data before you are willing to answer them.

1038663692856975361.text: No need for fire/water proofing.  The safe will be storing a backup copy of a thing in case the original copy is destroyed (odds of both being destroyed at the same time are unfathomably low).

1038663195106242562.text: It would seem that the home safe business tends to favor "recoverability" over "security", meaning they optimize for making the safe easy to get into when the owner forgets their key.  I need the opposite, I need it to require a plasma torch and a lot of time to "recover".

1038662935281692673.text: Crowdsourcing recommendations on physical safes that don't have backdoors. My recent un-researched safe purchased resulted in me buying a safe that not only has serious security vulnerabilities, but also contains a manufacturer back door. I need something better.

1034359684730216448.text: Luckily for me, the purpose of the safe was primarily to deter casual passerbys (e.g., service providers in the house) and to protect against fire.  The valuables in the safe will be secured on their own (e.g., Ledger HW wallet) or are inherently insecure (e.g., passport).

1034359193354952704.text: In the crypto-space, this would be akin to shipping a hardware wallet (e.g., ledger) with factory hard-coded mnemonic that is printed in plain text inside of a tamper-proof free box.

1034358795730706432.text: A bit of googling goes on to show that apparently the safe is not secure against anyone with a magnet and YouTube.  You simply put the magnet on the safe in the right spot and it unlocks, no hassle.

1034358615631585281.text: For starters, it comes with a factory code to unlock the safe printed on a manual stored inside an envelope.  The envelope doesn't have any tamper proofing and the factory code _cannot be disabled or changed_. This number printed in plain text will always unlock my safe.

1034358337763069954.text: Every now and then I go to the store and buy something non-trivial without doing a ton of online research.  Every time I regret the decision.  This time, it was a home safe.  This safe is slightly more secure than a drawer.

The argument for Ethereum Recovery Proposals is really an argument for property rights.  In this case, property rights are in conflict with immutability.

Why do people prefer immutability even at the cost of maintaining property rights?
